awd_titl_txt: Developing a Noyce Teacher Education Community of Practice to Broaden Participation and Build Capacity of Minority-serving Institutions in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce), this workshop hosted by the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network aims to serve the national need of increasing the diversity of the STEM teacher workforce. Through this effort, the project will serve a long-term goal of improving the representation of students of color in K-12 mathematics and science coursework, undergraduate STEM majors, and the STEM workforce. Relative to the composition of kindergarten through twelfth grade students in the United States, the current teaching force lacks racial and gender diversity. Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) have the potential to produce significant numbers of teachers from diverse backgrounds. Through Noyce support, MSIs have the potential to offer incentives for STEM undergraduates to pursue K-12 teaching careers. 

The QEM Network will use organizational learning to meet the following objectives in three phases: (1) Initiation Phase - Conduct one webinar per year (over two years) targeting approximately 500 potential PIs and administrators from 100 MSIs to discuss institutional and individual readiness for preparing a competitive Noyce proposal and the social and civic responsibility of MSIs to advance diversity in STEM teaching; (2) Engagement Phase - Provide one workshop per year (over two years) for MSI faculty members to connect Noyce proposal ideas to larger societal needs for diversity in STEM teaching; and (3) Maintenance Phase - Provide ongoing tailored post-workshop guidance focused on enhancing participants' ability to complete and submit competitive Noyce proposals and reinforce societal needs for diversity in STEM teaching. This project will assist with developing tools that help MSIs to compete for the resources necessary to provide measurable resources to their STEM education students, so that their students can become STEM teachers who make important contributions to our nation. The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts and experienced, exemplary K-12 STEM teachers to become STEM master teachers. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Between 2019 and 2023, with support from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Award #1900664, the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network conducted seven workshops and one webinar to provide technical assistance to minority-serving institutions (MSIs) to increase their participation and competitiveness in NSF’s Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program. Workshop participants included two person teams consisting of a STEM faculty member and a teacher education faculty member from MSIs with accredited teacher education programs. Through this project, MSIs capacity was strengthened through proposal development support, exposure to potential collaborators, and enhancement to their overall infrastructure to support STEM education initiatives. By providing resources and support to MSIs, these grants help attract and train more diverse cohorts of future STEM teachers ultimately helping create more inclusive learning environments for all students.

Over the period of this award, 262 faculty members from 87 distinct colleges and universities (51 HBCUs, 22 HSIs, 6 AANAPISIs/HSIs, 5 PWIs, 2 ANNH/AANAPISI, and 1 PBI) attended the eight QEM/Noyce sponsored events. The workshops and webinar provided a platform for faculty to network with peers at other institutions and exchange ideas.

The QEM Noyce Workshops provided hands-on training in the preparation and submission of competitive proposals to the NSF Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program as well as professional development focused on current teacher education research and best practices. The workshops were designed to equip participants with the necessary skills and knowledge to successfully secure funding from the NSF for their teacher education programs. The agenda topics and other relevant materials were selected to augment the workshop’s training and professional development. The interactive nature of the workshops allowed for a collaborative learning experience where participants could share their own experiences and learn from each other's successes and failures.

NSF Awards to Workshops Participants: A search of NSF’s awards database revealed that since convening the first workshop under this grant in 2019, twenty-two teams at minority serving institutions (MSIs) who participated in QEM sponsored Noyce workshops have been awarded a total of over $20M in Noyce awards (see visual Map). This significant amount of funding to MSIs highlights the importance and impact of the Noyce program in supporting STEM education and addressing teacher shortages by these institutions. 

Research funding obtained through successful research proposals submitted by Noyce participants would help ensure faculty have access to resources for the conduct of research on MSIs campuses and students get scholarships to pursue STEM education. This increased capacity, in turn, improves student access to quality undergraduate education and research opportunities; promotes the integration of research and teaching; and enhances faculty scholarly productivity overall.

About QEM: The QEM Network was established in 1990 as a non-profit organization in Washington, DC, dedicated to improving education for minorities throughout the nation. QEM works with minority and non-minority individuals, organizations, and institutions to help coordinate and energize efforts to improve the education of minorities, particularly in STEM. QEM’s technical assistance projects support institutional efforts to ensure that students who graduate with degrees in STEM disciplines are well-prepared to successfully pursue STEM graduate study or transition into the STEM workforce.
